identified-content.classifier: Health Maintenance Organizations and Managed Care

abstract.p: Dr Jean-Claude Bystryn letter notes that HMOs introduce additional, very expensive, layer of bureaucracy between payers and providers (S)

block.p: The obvious conclusion to be drawn from the increasing number of health maintenance organizations deserting Medicare (front page, June 3) is that they cannot deliver cost-effective care. This is not surprising since they introduce an additional, and very expensive, layer of bureaucracy between payers and providers.

The obvious conclusion to be drawn from the increasing number of health maintenance organizations deserting Medicare (front page, June 3) is that they cannot deliver cost-effective care. This is not surprising since they introduce an additional, and very expensive, layer of bureaucracy between payers and providers.

In the early days, H.M.O.'s justified this expense by saying care was being provided more efficiently. But after a decade or so, they have squeezed the fat out of the system. The problem is not that Medicare reimbursement levels are too low, but that H.M.O. expenses -- like profits for shareholders and generous salaries for executives -- are too high.
JEAN-CLAUDE BYSTRYN, M.D. New York, June 6, 2000
The writer is director of the melanoma program at the Kaplan Comprehensive Cancer Center at N.Y.U.
